Award.AwardTitle: UNS: Engineering protein sensors to detect epigenetic changes during stem cell culture

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
1512285 Yuan, Chongli

DNA methylation is important in regulating gene activity , and in a cell population cells may have exhibit different levels of methylation, which results in behaviors that vary from the population average. Understanding the methylation level changes in individual cells is important in many biological applications. In this project the researchers will develop a novel method which will enable measurement of methylation at a single-cell level.

Intellectual Merit: Current detection approaches for quantifying DNA methylation are limited because they preclude single-cell analysis and real-time monitoring of epigenetic changes. The researchers propose to design a probe by combining protein engineering principles and modern fluorescence detection techniques. Three objectives will be pursued: engineer and validate molecular sensors that detect methylated DNA near a gene locus, optimize the probes for use with cell extracts, and evaluate the genetically-encoded probe within live cells. Additionally, methylation level changes during stem cell passaging will also be measured.

Broader Impacts: The proposed probe has the capability to significantly improve detecting DNA methylation levels at a single cell and potentially enable monitoring of dynamic changes. The research project provides a multidisciplinary training opportunity for engineers. The PIs will involve undergraduate students in research and encourage the participation of minority and female students. This proposal will also support the continued collaboration with the Women in Engineering Program and develop a new laboratory module for engaging students with the concept of fluorescence-based detection techniques.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Our objective in this proposal is to engineer and optimize a protein-based probe to reveal DNA methylation at a specific gene of interest at a single-cell level. As a part of our proposed research, the next generation of engineers are trained and inspired through their active participation in this work. The project has provided training opportunities for four graduate students. One of the students is Hispanic and two are female. Undergraduate researchers were recruited to work on this project with a focus on under-represented minorities. A significant number of participating undergraduate students (> 70%) have enrolled in graduate programs in the STEM field motivated by their research experience.

Intellectually, we have successfully developed the probes as planned and demonstrated its applicability in quantifying DNA methylation levels in both cell extracts and live cells. The developed technology can be used to track the “aging” and “healthy” status of various cells. The design principle of the DNA methylation probe was found modular and extendable for other types of epigenetic modifications that we have subsequently demonstrated in our publications. The developed probes were applied to study how human cells respond to environmental chemicals, including heavy metal and herbicide. These studies provide unique insights about the underlying molecular mechanism of toxicology that is otherwise in accessible via conventional technologies. The probe was shared among the scientific community to enable various types of research, including cancer, toxicology and aging research. Our findings have been shared among the scientific community via peer reviewed journal articles and presentations at scientific conference. The PI and co-PI were also engaged in various outreach activities that help to increase public knowledge of DNA methylation and epigenetics. The team has published in Chemical Engineering Progress magazine that has a large audience outside the academic world to facilitate the dissemination of our results to broad public.
